content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. Simeon Saunders Booker, Jr. was born in Baltimore, Maryland in 1918. He became interested in journalism in Youngstown, Ohio and wrote about Negro League baseball teams. Booker won awards for his reporting on racial inequities and received a Nieman Fellowship from Harvard University in 1950. Simeon Saunders Booker, Jr. became the first full-time African-American reporter at The Washington Post after leaving Harvard in 1951. He played a significant role in advancing the civil rights movement through his coverage of the Emmett Till murder and trial in 1955, as well as reporting on the integration of Central High School in Little Rock, Arkansas in 1957. In 1961, he rode with the Congress on Racial Equality (CORE) Freedom Riders through the Deep South, and helped rescue them when they were attacked in Anniston, Alabama. Simeon Saunders Booker, Jr. was a pioneering African-American reporter who played a significant role in advancing the civil rights movement. He interviewed Black troops in Vietnam, chronicled American history in acclaimed books, and was known as the "dean of the black press" for his work at Ebony and Jet magazines. Simeon Saunders Booker, Jr. covered every Presidential election since the Eisenhower Administration during his fifty-three years with Johnson Publishing. In 1982, he received the National Press Club's Fourth Estate Award and was honored with various prestigious awards throughout his career. Simeon Saunders Booker, Jr. received several prestigious awards during his career, including the Communicators Award in 1998, the Phoenix Award in 2010, and induction into the Hall of Fame by the National Association of Black Journalists in 2013. Simeon Saunders Booker, Jr. will be presented with a Congressional Gold Medal for his achievements in journalism, including reporting during the Civil Rights movement. The medal will be designed and struck by the Secretary of the Treasury. Additionally, duplicate medals will be made. The Secretary has the authority to create and sell duplicate bronze medals of the gold medal at a price covering all costs. The medals produced under this Act are considered national medals and numismatic items under specific sections of the United States Code.
